annevk - I commented over on #html-wg about your link pointing to XForms WG aiming at Turing completeness

If all working groups were expected/required to working under the expectation that all major features of their specs should be explicitly mentioned in their charters, I wonder what the verdict would be on the XForms WG resolution to add a capability for user-defined functions.
looking at the XForms charter, almost none of its actual features are mentioned in the scope section or anywhere else in that charter at all.
yeah, dunno
I thought part of the idea of XForms was that it was not turing complete so that you can "reason" about it or something

annevk - I think it's great for it to evolve along to meet whatever is needed by the people who are actually using it or want to use it. But I think it would be hard for anybody to claim that the group's charter gives an accurate description of the scope of what XForms has evolved into or what they seem to be further evolving it into.
If that charter were held to the same standard that some seem to expect the HTML WG charter to be held to, it would need to be a lot more explicit about particular features than it is now.

the main problems people have documented with longdesc are that the vast majority of longdesc attributes out there are wrong in various ways
so following longdesc whenever possible would be actively harmful to the user

Actually, I think a lot of that documentation shows longdesc being misinterpreted as a string value rather than a URI.
taken together that makes the feature seem somewhat unsuccessful in achieving its intended purpose
Which means it can be used for error correction of alternative text where necessary.
I do not think that's the case
what Hixie found is that many longdescs are links to the image itself, links to the site's top-level page, 404s, irrelevant spam links, stuff like that

The "blind users" being "unaware" is entirely down to the UI and documentation of assistive tech. (And in fact it's quite clearly documented.) Never mind we're talking about tiny sample sizes of people and a tiny sample of sites.

however, it seems to be the case that very few (less than 1 in 100,000) pages use it, and of those, at best 1 in 1000 use it correctly (that's just eliminate longdescs that simple testing can show you are wrong)

it's true, HTML 4.01 says "This attribute specifies a link to a long description of the image", but I think it has to be assumed it's not intended for general audiences because then a normal link would be better
othermaciej: Yeah but it's emphatically not just targeted at disabled users.
note the rationale given for ALT: http://www.w3.org/TR/html4/struct/objects.html#adef-alt

In an ideal world, it would always be good to give authors the opportunity to express accessibility information/metadata visibly. In the real world, publishers are never going to always choose to do so. Therefore there will always be a set of publishers willing to express accessibility information/metadata "invisibly" (to some degree) and not visibly.
that set seems to be very small today, though

So while I think the "hidden metadata is evil" argument is a powerful argument for allowing ways to explicitly markup visible content as being a genuine equivalent for some other bit of content, I don't think it's a real-world argument for preventing authors providing "invisible" equivalents/metadata.

takkaria: On the contrary, it's vast. ALT is one of the more successful accessibility features. Microformats have been surprisingly successful, given that while they preach visible metadata they practice a lot of invisible metadata.
(a lot of key data is buried in TITLE attributes)
I can't imagine a solution where to provide text for a image button you would have needed to make it visible would have been half as successful.
It certainly doesn't parallel the model adopted for desktop UIs.

true, but given that many people are willing to use alt text, the fact that most of those same people aren't willing to use longdesc, means that the number of people who actually want to provide longdesc must be fairly small
takkaria: Again clearly false, given alt is /heavily/ evangelized, and longdesc, where mentioned at all by evangelists, has generally being accompanied by caveats about it not being supported.
alt is just text. longdesc requires a whole webpage.
